Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Touch-free Voice Trigger for Power Constrained Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to bring positive impactful changes to the economy, society, and scientific/technological understanding through intelligent voice-enabled technology. Commercially, the introduction of an intelligent, ultra-low power, embedded voice trigger will capture an important portion of the $113 billion global voice and speech recognition market, contributing to its expansion and that of related markets such as wearables and Internet of Things (IoT). The long-term potential impact is broad and encompasses the key players in the voice recognition ecosystem such as the mobile phone industry, semiconductor companies, chip designers, technology providers and system integrators, who will be enabled to innovate with the proposed platform. Societally, the day-to-day lives of users will be made easier by empowering them through the faster and natural use of speech commands to access device functionality and to retrieve processed information in real time. Furthermore, by performing onboard speech processing, the proposed technology alleviates many societal issues and challenges surrounding privacy and data protection with cloud-based solutions.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to develop an always-on, touch-free, embedded voice trigger with ultra-low power consumption for deployment in smart products and IoT systems. This novel speech processing technology transforms analog speech signals into biologically-inspired data-efficient binary pulse trains and processes them using adaptive state models. These models can be deployed in a network of reprogrammable automata with high accuracy using only the timing information of the digital pulses produced by the user's voice. Compared with conventional speech features, pulse trains, as used in the human auditory system, are highly robust to noise and lead to extremely small footprint hardware implementations, which are ideally suited for low power on-chip processing. Furthermore, by processing only ones and zeros with automata, the proposed approach requires no arithmetic, enabling real-time, complex voice processing capability that would otherwise be achieved at prohibitive costs or be relegated to the cloud. This keyword spotting technology is pre-configurable, customized for each user, and can be used in cellphones or similar portable devices with no network connection required after calibration. It offers increased security and privacy to access portable device features by eliminating the need to send potentially sensitive data continuously online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advanced the frontiers of knowledge, strengthened commercial viability, and enabled positive impactful changes to society. Over the past nine months, Pulsics strived to develop an always-on, touch-free, on-device voice trigger with ultra-low power consumption for mobile devices connected to voice-controlled intelligent personal assistants and other internet-connected products. The key intellectual merit of the proposed project consists of two parts. The first is a brain-inspired process that enables sparse low-power representation of audio signals. The second is a novel adaptive method that learns to recognize patterns from the brain-inspired signals. Once trained, this knowledge can be translated into a set of rules and applied without explicit computation, further reducing the implementation complexity and power consumption. Together, they enable a data and power efficient automatic speech recognition engine that is ideally suited for off-line continuous detection of keywords for wearables, smartphones, and other mobile devices.

 

There are two major outcomes from Phase I. First, we established the feasibility of capturing a continuous space of dynamics with a discrete set of states. This enables us to distill the knowledge learned directly from the brain-inspired patterns into a finite set of simple transitions. We benchmarked the performance of the transition rules using the TI-46 speech data, consisting of 16 speakers (eight females and eight males) each speaking 26 utterances of the digits zero through nine. Results demonstrated that rule or transition based recognition engine can effectively distinguish spoken words independent of speaker. Second, we obtained preliminary power consumption measurements by implementing our novel algorithm using a programmable hardware. Results show that two orders of magnitude in power reduction can be achieved using the proposed approach, compared to conventional implementation.

 

Based on the findings, we established the feasibility for positive impactful changes to the economy, society, and scientific/technological understanding through low-power, on-device, intelligent voice-enabled technology. As electronics become increasingly smaller, physical limits begin to prevent engineers from making them faster and more power-efficient. Furthermore, the cost of scalability has stopped falling. The industry is moving towards designs that drive down power consumption, rather than the size of individual components. Further compounding the problem is the fact that conventional machine learning algorithms are not designed with energy efficiency in mind. This power constraint in mobile computing has reached a critical point. Many smart devices in the market today are actually less intelligent than our current capabilities because heavy on-device processing significantly compromises battery life. The current push is heavy reliance on cloud computing, which creates fundamental problems in quality of service, mobility, safety, privacy, and security. Innovation in computation must be pursued to make devices more capable and scalable for tasks involving complex computational intelligence. Our technology addresses these important problems from a fundamentally new perspective: modify the representation of information in signals collected from the external world as pulses, mimicking the exquisite power efficacy of the brain. This has allowed us to be competitive with the performance of existing systems, using algorithms that are orders of magnitude more power efficient than conventional designs. Minimally, we can reduce the power spent in transmitting the information in-and-out of the devices to the cloud and apply it for local processing with equivalence performance, mitigating all the issues mentioned above. Moving forward, Pulsics plan to accelerate our commercialization activity through rapid prototyping for evaluation with industry partners.
